Table 1: Anthropometric data of adult men and wom-en—mean values and ranges
datumwomenmen
meanrangemeanrange
age (yr.)2819-412919-39
height (in.)6562-686968-75
weight (lb.)119109–14014296–176
skinfold (mm.)136–2062–11
arm circumference (mm.)240180–260250180–280
fat area (cm.²)146–1973–11
using values in Food Values of Portions Commonly Used (17) and Agriculture Handbooks No. 8 and 34 (18,19). To express the nutrient intake as percentage of the Recommended Dietary Allowances (20), the adults were classified, by sex, into two age-groups (nineteen to twenty-two and twenty-three to fifty years) as were the children (one to three years and four to six), whose dietary intakes were recorded by their mothers. Results and discussion Sixty ten-day dietary records were obtained from fifty adults and ten children. The average age, height, weight, triceps skinfold thickness, arm circumference, and fat area of the adults (twenty-one women and twenty-nine men) are presented in Table 1. Accord- ing to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's ta- ble (21), none of the adults was below his/her desir- able weight, although all were at the low limit of the normal range. Average triceps skinfold thicknesses of the men and women were 50 and 57 per cent, re- spectively, of normal values; according to figures es- tablished in the Ten-State Survey (23), they would fall in the 15th percentile; the arm circumference of both the men and women would fall in the 5th percen- tile (22,23). The fat area for the men was half that of the women. Interestingly, most of the subjects re- ported having lost weight on this diet, although no at- tempt was made to quantify weight loss. The majority of the subjects lived in study houses or with spouses and had a relatively high level of edu- cation (Table 2). The average educational level was that of a junior in college (fifteen years). Several men were employed in a warehouse-distribution cen- ter which specialized in natural foods, where they were engaged in moderate work. The remainder of the men and all of the women were in occupations in- volving light activity. Most of the subjects had been practicing macrobi-otics for at least a year. Natural or organic foods bought from natural food distribution centers or from farms were generally used. The subjects realized that they paid more for these foods but believed they were worth the extra cost. These were supplemented with foods from local groceries and supermarkets. The ma-jority ate at macrobiotic or health food restaurants occasionally, some as often as twice a week.
Table 2: Demographic data adult subjectson the
datumnumber of subjects
living condition in study house29
with spouse14
with someone5
alone2
educational level* attended college at least 2 years26
bachelor's degree11
master's degree3
doctorate1
registered nurse2
employment women
homemaker8
cook7
student4
clerk2
men
warehouse distribution center13
waiter2
caretaker of study house3
clerk1
engineer1
musician1
student3
other5
macrobiotics practice
at least one year41
at least five years9
*Average educational level: 15 years.
All of the adult subjects believed the diet improved their health, and 90 per cent had additional reasons for following it. Few claimed to be strict vegetarians, and the dietary records indicate that none was following high levels of the Zen macrobiotic regimen or was an extreme vegetarian. DIET CONTENT. Table 3 shows the wide variety and rather common use of some non-vegetarian foods in the diets of these subjects. Eggs were more frequently eaten as such than used as an ingredient, while milk was used in coffee and chowder but only by one individual as a beverage. A wide variety of cheese and fish was reported. Chicken was recorded by one family and turkey, bacon, and ham by two individuals. A few subjects ate such commercial items as bagels, ice cream, and yogurt. All ate a large and varied amount of vegetables and used the tops of carrots, cauliflower, turnips, and beets, further indicating that the diet was not an extreme form, i.e., composed primarily of grains. These rather large quantities of vegetables were, of course, good sources of carotene and ascorbic acid. As expected, grains appeared frequently and formed the base of the diet. Those commonly used were brown rice, buckwheat, and millet. They were often eaten in combination with legumes, such as aduki or pinto beans, thus enhancing protein intake. 456 Research Journal of The American Dietetic Association Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/qpbx0227
